Ebenezer Scrooge.Action: Scrooge's name was good on the London Exchange for anything he chose to put his hand to.
Scrooge is bundling up his coat and heading for the exit while at the Exchange, indicating business-like and efficient behavior.
Dismisses Christmas as a humbug and refuses to engage in festive cheer.
Ignores and avoids acknowledging a poorly-dressed man in need.
Refuses to offer leniency or empathy regarding a debt owed, insisting on payment despite man's hardship.
Advocates leaving the debtor's wife behind to avoid her imprisonment, showing lack of compassion.
Dismisses a man's plea for leniency regarding his wife's debt, shows no sympathy and abruptly ends the conversation.
Physically rejects the man by shaking him off when he clutches Scrooge's sleeve.
Refuses to offer charity or consider the personal circumstances of a debtor, showing a focus on financial repayment over human concern.
Dismisses the relevance of Christmas and emotions to business matters, demonstrating a clear, unwavering stance and focus on his priorities.
Walks away abruptly when interrupted, showing a lack of patience or social skill in dealing with others.
Responds to Fred's merry Christmas greeting with 'Bah! Humbug' and dismisses Christmas as a time for fools and misery.
Questions Fred's right to be merry due to poverty while ignoring his own good fortune, showing intolerance and curmudgeonly behavior.
Refuses to engage positively with Fred, insisting on his own way of 'keeping Christmas' and rejecting the holiday’s cheer.
Confidently asserts his cynical views on Christmas and criticizes societal norms regarding money and celebration.
Fails to provide a reasoned response when challenged about his dismal outlook; repeats 'Bah! Humbug' without elaboration.
Uses sharp language and rhetorical questions to dominate the conversation, showing control over the interaction.
Fails to consider the valid merits of others’ perspectives or feelings, leading to social alienation.
Describes Christmas as a kind, forgiving, charitable, pleasant time, acknowledging its goodness in general terms.
Threatens Bob Cratchit with job loss for applauding Christmas remarks.
Dismisses nephew Fred’s invitation to Christmas dinner with a sarcastic and hostile retort.
Rejects Fred’s friendly and conciliatory attempts to be friends without any request for help.
Dismisses Christmas as meaningless and shows no interest in family or social connection, giving curt replies.
Threatens Bob Cratchit with job loss to enforce discipline and obedience.
Sarcastically compliments nephew’s speaking ability, demonstrating sharp observation.
Responds repeatedly with 'Good afternoon' to evade sincere emotional interaction and invitation.
Refuses to donate to charity, dismisses the poor, shows no sympathy for suffering.
Insists on prisons and workhouses handling the poor, rejects personal responsibility.
States he wishes to be left alone and does not celebrate Christmas.
Frowns, shakes head, and promptly returns the credentials of the charity collector, showing decisiveness and control over the situation.
Asks pointed questions about prisons, workhouses, and the Poor Law, showing knowledge of social institutions and critical thinking.
Firmly refuses to contribute any money to charity, clearly communicating his boundaries and stance.
Dismisses the plight of the poor without empathy or consideration for alternative perspectives, demonstrating a lack of social awareness.
Shows rigidity and closed-mindedness by rejecting charity outright despite the appeal, limiting his adaptability and broader understanding.
Refuses to give Bob Cratchit Christmas Day off without pay; complains about fairness of holiday and accuses it of 'picking a man's pocket'.
Pays Bob Cratchit a full day's wages despite no work done, even while grumbling.
Leaves workplace with a growl, indicating displeasure but no aggressive or abusive behavior toward Bob Cratchit.
Manages his counting-house with strictness and attention to closing time, ensuring work stops promptly at the hour.
Observes the church clock striking the hour and uses it as a signal to end the workday, demonstrating time awareness and discipline.
Insists Bob Cratchit works on Christmas Day and resents paying wages for no work, displaying little empathy but a firm grasp on financial control.
Neglects to show compassion or flexibility towards Bob Cratchit's need for Christmas off, which could harm employee morale.
Uses firm language and clear commands to Bob Cratchit about work expectations and schedule, indicating confident and direct communication.
Walks out growling, appearing grumpy and ill-tempered, which may undermine personal effectiveness despite capability.
Studies his banker's-book carefully during dinner, showing attention to his financial affairs and business details.
Lives alone in a large but dark and foreboding building, suggesting possible neglect of personal or social well-being.
Investigates the strange phenomenon of the knocker turning into Marley's face with caution and curiosity, showing an observational attitude and presence of mind.
Gasps in surprise at the image of Marley's face, indicating a momentary loss of composure or being unsettled by the supernatural.
Cautiously enters his dark, gloomy house with suspicion and unease, checking every room thoroughly to ensure nothing is amiss.
Locks himself in his room securely to avoid surprises.
Sits alone eating a low fire and simple gruel while feeling unsettled by ghostly signs.
Double-locks his door to secure himself against surprise.
Mistakes his dressing gown for a ghostly apparition initially, indicating momentary fear or confusion.
Calmly returns to bed and prepares for the night after securing himself.
Paces the room and observes his surroundings attentively when unsettled by strange occurrences.
Shows nervousness and unease at supernatural events, reflected by his glances and unease.
Cracks a joke upon seeing Marley's ghost, attempts to defuse his terror with humor.
Addresses Marley coldly and caustically, showing skepticism and lack of friendliness.
Maintains a sarcastic and joking attitude to deflect fear when confronted by Marley's ghost.
Questions the ghost directly and tries to understand his identity and purpose, showing curiosity and presence of mind.
Doubts Marley's ability to sit down and then promptly tells him to do so when confirmed, demonstrating logical thinking and confidence.
Initially refuses to believe in the supernatural events despite clear evidence, showing closed-mindedness.
Dismisses the ghost's reality with skepticism and sarcasm, calling the apparition 'humbug.'
Clutches his hands and kneels in fear, begging the apparition for mercy.
Questions the reality of the ghost and tries to rationalize what he sees using logical reasoning (e.g., doubting senses due to possible stomach disorder).
Threatens to swallow the toothpick to test if the apparition is real, demonstrating a skeptical and testing approach.
Is overwhelmed and falls to his knees clasping his hands, showing loss of composure and being unnerved by the apparition.
Asks Marley to tell him more and to speak comfort, showing a moment of vulnerability and desire for understanding.
Glances about expecting to see the chain Marley describes, showing a degree of imagination and engagement with the situation.
Questions Marley somewhat skeptically about his wandering and being slow, showing a lack of empathy or warmth toward Marley's suffering.
Questions Marley about the reasons spirits walk the earth, showing curiosity and seeking understanding.
Glances about the floor expecting to see physical evidence of the chain Marley described, showing skepticism and a failure to grasp the spiritual nature of the warning.
Asks Marley for comfort and more information, demonstrating some level of rational engagement and desire to comprehend his fate.

Makes a sarcastic remark about Marley being 'slow' in traveling after death, which undercuts the seriousness of the situation and may reflect a lack of emotional intelligence or situational awareness.
Shows concern and listens to Marley's remorseful warnings.
Refers to Marley as 'a good man of business,' emphasizing commercial success over human kindness.
Asks Marley not to be hard on him and to avoid flowery speech, indicating defensiveness and emotional resistance.
Asks Marley practical questions about his travels and shows curiosity about the ghost's condition.
Acknowledges Marley was a good businessman, indicating recognition of business acumen.
Shows physical signs of fear and discomfort (shivering, wiping sweat) when confronted with supernatural elements, indicating some loss of composure.
Interjects to prevent Marley from being 'flowery', showing an attempt to be direct and pragmatic.
Expresses gratitude to Marley, calling him a good friend.
Responds to the warning about impending spirits with reluctance and fear.
Stops in surprise and fear at Marley's warning and listens to lamentation and regret.
Follows to the window, desperate in his curiosity about the phantoms and their suffering.
Examines the double-locked door after the ghost's visit and tries to dismiss the experience as 'Humbug!' but stops.
Goes to bed without undressing after the ghost's visit, appearing resigned or unsettled.
Stops at Marley's raised hand showing situational awareness and self-control despite fear.
Examines the door and notes that the double-locks are undisturbed, showing careful observation and attention to detail.
Attempts to dismiss the supernatural event by saying 'Humbug!' but stops mid-word, indicating internal conflict and some doubt about his own judgment.
Goes to bed without undressing and falls asleep instantly, showing practicality and ability to rest efficiently.
Scrambles out of bed and gropes his way to the window in semi-darkness, indicating some clumsiness or lack of preparedness for unexpected events.
Demonstrates vigilance and a cautious approach by staying awake to await a mysterious visitor.
Shows an ambiguous sigh (relief, disappointment, or embarrassment) and eventually goes back to sleep with a peaceful, satisfied look.
Starts up with surprise and fear upon seeing the Ghost of Christmas Past, addresses the spirit respectfully as 'sir'.
Immediately sits up and faces the unearthly visitor with alertness and courage.
Directly asks the spirit if it is the one foretold to him, showing clarity of mind and recognition of the situation.
Requests the Ghost to put on a hat to lessen the brightness of its light.
Politely acknowledges the Ghost's intention for his welfare but prefers sleep over immediate attention.
Expresses concern for his physical safety and mortality when asked to rise and walk with the Ghost in the cold night.
Clasping hands together nostalgically upon seeing his childhood home area.
Questions the Ghost of Christmas Past about its identity and purpose, cautiously trying to understand the situation.
Expresses concern about physical safety and practical limitations (wearing slippers, nightgown, vulnerability to cold) before following the ghost.
Asks the ghost to put a hat on to diminish its light, showing a lack of respect for the supernatural presence and some stubbornness.
Complies with the ghost's invitation to walk despite initial hesitation, showing adaptability and openness to experience.
His lip trembles and he catches his voice recalling his childhood, showing a vulnerable and sentimental side.
Refers to the tear on his cheek as 'a pimple,' indicating reluctance to openly show emotion.
Points out every familiar detail of his childhood home readily, demonstrating a deep personal connection to his past.
His eye glistens coldly at the joyful boys passing by and their merry Christmas wishes.
Grimly acknowledges the solitary child left behind at school (himself), recognizing his own neglect and isolation.
Remembers the location and details of his former school very clearly and confidently, even saying he could walk it blindfold.
Displays emotional vulnerability and physical signs of distress (lip trembling) but still maintains composure and proceeds with the Spirit's guidance.
Weeps to see his poor forgotten self as he used to be.
Says 'Poor boy!' observing his younger self alone and cold.
Expresses regret for not giving money to a boy singing carols at his window.
Feels anxious and mournful observing his younger self's loneliness.
Is amazed and contemplative seeing his sister Fan comforting his younger self.
Sits quietly and weeps upon seeing his younger self at school, showing emotional reflection but no active problem-solving.
Muttered and put his hand in his pocket rather than taking direct action to help the boy singing carols, expressing regret but passivity.
Recognizes and emotionally connects with his sister Fan and his younger self, demonstrating self-awareness and insight.
Watches young Scrooge and Fan with quiet approval and acknowledges her large heart.
Observes quietly and attentively the departure of his younger self and Fan without interrupting or reacting emotionally.
Shows awareness and reflective understanding of Fan's gentle and large-hearted nature when prompted by the Ghost.
Allows himself to be led emotionally by memories instead of actively trying to control or deny the emotional impact.
Participates actively and joyfully in Fezziwig's Christmas party, laughing and engaging with others.
Charges into the street with the shutters and helps put them up quickly and efficiently.
Follows his younger self around the room, listens in on conversations and laughs, showing engagement and social awareness.
Laughs along with jokes and watches young self dance at Fezziwig's warm, lively party.
Expresses admiration for Fezziwig's generosity and kindness toward his employees.
Silent observer of Fezziwig’s warm actions rather than engaging himself.
Observes the party carefully and appreciates the skill and joy of Fezziwig's dancing and festivities.
Calls the gratitude of the 'silly folks' a 'small matter' dismissively when prompted by the Ghost.
Engages attentively with the apprentices' conversation and reflects thoughtfully on Fezziwig's generosity and celebration style.
Acknowledges Fezziwig's kindness and the importance of making work pleasant despite the low cost.
Expresses a desire to say a word or two to his clerk, indicating some regret or kindness.
Stops and is reluctant to speak further when questioned, suggesting emotional restraint or avoidance.
Watches Belle placing flowers by a tombstone with an expression of astonishment and a gentle whisper of her name.
Reaches out to touch Belle but does not follow through, indicating hesitation or unresolved feelings.
Articulates insightfully about the power of a master's behavior toward servants, recognizing the value of happiness given freely rather than costly expenditure.
Attempts to communicate a word or two to his clerk, showing self-awareness and a wish to influence others positively.
Watches quietly and attentively the scene involving Belle, showing observation and emotional awareness.
Stops speaking suddenly when ghost questions him, showing some hesitation or internal conflict.
Tries to be reasonable in conversation, denies change toward Belle despite evidence.
Admits he is not the same man he was, but shows impatience and defensiveness.
Denies seeking release from engagement despite clear emotional distance.
Tries to reason about the difficulties of poverty and justifies his pursuit of wealth logically.
Fails to recognize how much he has changed and how his priorities have alienated Belle, despite her clear explanation.
Answers impatiently and defensively rather than reflecting on meaningful criticism from Belle.
Is able to maintain composure and keep the conversation focused despite emotional challenge.
Reluctantly accepts the justice of Belle's words and seems to yield to them despite himself.
Desires to stop witnessing painful memories and asks to be spared further emotional torture by the spirit.
Acknowledges Belle's insight about his nature and the consequences of his choices with some degree of understanding.
Begins to plead with the spirit to stop showing painful memories, showing emotional vulnerability and some loss of control.
Watches Belle's family with awe and silent longing, reflecting on what might have been had he chosen differently.
Remains a silent observer, does not engage with the joyful family or children around him.
Feels great distress and terror upon seeing the vision of Belle and his lost past warmth; tries to escape and violently attacks the Ghost.
Prepares himself to confront supernatural events and cautiously investigates strange occurrences in his home.
Wakes up at the predicted time prepared for the second spirit, steeling himself for anything strange.
After waiting for a long time with no apparition, he calmly checks the clock, sighs, and decides to go back to bed.
Despite his nervousness, he quietly and carefully unlocks and opens the door to the sitting-room on hearing his name called.
Enters the room timidly and does not look at the Ghost of Christmas Present's kind eyes.
Enters the room timidly, does not look the Ghost of Christmas Present in the eyes.
Acknowledges he has never seen the Ghost of Christmas Present before.
Expresses interest in learning from the Spirit, acknowledges past mistakes.
Holds fast to the Spirit's robe as instructed, showing openness and cooperation.
Observes Bob Cratchit's home and family quietly, showing a tender curiosity.
Acknowledges a lesson learned from last night and asks the Spirit to teach him so he may profit by it.
Follows the Spirit's instructions promptly and holds onto the robe as told.
Watches silently and observes the Cratchit family's warmth and care for each other, showing quiet interest.
No direct interaction or warmth shown towards the Cratchit family in this excerpt.
Observes the Cratchit family with attention and surprise, indicating awareness and ability to perceive details previously unknown to him.
Has no prior knowledge of whose house he is visiting until this scene, showing a lack of attentiveness or preparation.
Dismisses the Cratchit family Christmas dinner and remarks 'Not much of a goose.'
Dismisses the Cratchits' Christmas dinner by saying 'Not much of a goose....' in a matter-of-fact tone.
Comments dismissively on the goose, saying 'Hmmph. Not much of a goose.'
Watches the Cratchit family warmly and with fascination, showing attention to their affection and struggles.
Asks the Spirit to reveal if Tiny Tim will live, revealing concern for the child's wellbeing.
Initially voices harsh, dismissive thoughts about the poor and Tiny Tim’s potential death, echoing his earlier coldness.
Is overcome with penitence and grief upon hearing his own cruel words echoed back by the Spirit.
Scrooge accepts the toast made by Bob Cratchit and hears Mrs. Cratchit's harsh words without protest, then quietly turns away, feeling like the 'Ogre' of the family.
Scrooge shows visible reaction to being confronted with his negative reputation by the Cratchit family and his internal trembling before the Spirit's rebuke.
Startled but responsive when called by Bob Cratchit, shows some social awareness.
Turns away from the Cratchit family after realizing he is seen as the 'Ogre' of the family, indicating self-awareness but also avoidance.
Asks intelligently about the place he visits with the Spirit, demonstrating curiosity and inquiry.
Refuses to join family gatherings and disdains social company, isolating himself.
Is sorrowed over by Fred who tries to be charitable and pity him despite his unpleasantness.
Keeps time with his feet and quietly enjoys the dancing and company, showing some enjoyment and openness.
Suggests staying until the guests have departed, showing consideration for the hosts and social situation.
Keeps time with his feet to the music, quietly enjoying himself.
Suggests they stay at the party until the guests have departed, demonstrating social awareness and patience.
Scowls and silently tells others to 'shut up' while they play a guessing game involving him, showing reluctance to join in the fun.
Remains silent and visibly humiliated when others laugh at the game teasing him, not retaliating or engaging.
Attempts to participate in the guessing game by asking if the animal is a cow.
Scowls at The Spirit's silent admonition and tells others to 'shut up' so he can have fun.
Remains stunned and humiliated after being identified as the answer in the game and mocked by others.
Remains silent and humiliated during the niece and Fred's jovial and friendly toast.
Observes the destitute woman and the charity ward quietly without intervening or offering help.
Is stunned and humiliated at the family gathering, unable to respond appropriately to light-hearted teasing.
Exchanges glances with the Ghost, indicating some level of awareness of his situation during the events.
Observes others with curiosity and asks questions about the Spirit's condition.
Observes details carefully, such as the watch showing time just before midnight.
Questions the Spirit about its hair and the strange object protruding from its robe, showing curiosity and critical observation.
Expresses concern or hesitation in asking questions ('Forgive me if I am not justified in what I ask'), showing some social insecurity or lack of confidence.
Asks if the emaciated children belong to the spirit, shows concern by asking if they have refuge or resource.
Winces at the spirit's sarcastic reply about prisons and workhouses, indicating some internal discomfort or guilt.
Bends down respectfully before the silent, ominous Ghost of Christmas Yet To Come, showing humility or reverence.
Shows curiosity and attempts to understand the meaning of Ignorance and Want, asks if they have no refuge or resource.
Wincing at the Spirit's sarcastic suggestion of prisons and workhouses as solutions, indicating discomfort but not immediate constructive response.
Acknowledges the solemnity of the Ghost of Christmas Yet To Come by kneeling and showing appropriate reverence and attention.
Fails to immediately grasp the full implications of the spiritual warnings, remaining passive and reactive rather than proactive.
Acknowledges fear but accepts the Ghost of Christmas Yet To Come's guidance with gratitude and determination to change.
Follows the Spirit willingly despite fear, showing openness to transformation.
Observes the businessmen coldly, recognizing them as associates but showing no evident empathy for their reactions to his death.
Maintains strictly business demeanor and values standing in business esteem; observes others with skepticism and detachment.
Shows curiosity about the Phantom's purpose in showing trivial conversations, indicating a willingness to understand others more deeply.
Reflects on his usual corner and usual time without noticing his absence in the future, shows some self-awareness about change and hopes to have made resolutions.
Follows the Phantom into the bad part of town, witnessing the misery and filth of impoverished people.
Analyzes the significance of visions, tries to logically understand their relation to past and future events.
Observes surroundings carefully, notes time and place to validate his experience.
Shows some hesitation and uncertainty while expressing his hopes about personal change.
Follows the Phantom promptly and attentively despite his partial confusion.
Appears present silently while others discuss and joke about their grim business; no direct engagement or warmth shown toward others present.
Dies alone and neglected, prompting characters to remark on his wickedness and lack of natural kindness during his life.
Turns away in horror and disgust from the sight of his own belongings being taken as payment for debts.
Turns away from confronting the scene, expresses disgust, refuses to engage directly.
Shows awareness and fear that his lonely and uncared-for death might be his own fate.
Observes the handling of the belongings and body of a dead man with visible sickness and distress.
Hesitates and is visibly shaken when asked to look upon the dead man's face; acknowledges fear and emotional difficulty.
Plea to the Spirit to show him if anyone feels emotion caused by the dead man's death; expresses a desire to understand others' feelings.
Glances anxiously around a dark room to understand his surroundings.
Attempts to uncover the dead man's face to learn more but is physically and emotionally unable to do so.
Recognizes his emotional limitation and honestly admits he lacks the power to proceed.
Beseeches the Spirit to show him any person who feels emotion from the dead man's death, showing proactive engagement with the lesson.
Comments on the family's happiness at the death of a merciless creditor with apparent pleasure and lack of tenderness.
Observes the household's reaction to a debt collector's death and displays a cold, calculating attitude by noting the advantage their situation gains from the man's death.
Questions emotional responses (pleasure at death) with a cynical tone, showing an analytical and skeptical mindset.
Fails to show empathy or warmth despite understanding the situation, indicating a lack of emotional intelligence which can hinder overall competence in personal relations.
Quietly observes the Cratchit family in their modest home, showing curiosity and attentiveness to their situation.
Peers intently at the group, trying to understand the scene and emotions around him.
Expresses deep sorrow on realizing the Cratchit family's hardship ('Oh, my God...').
Watches quietly as the Cratchit family suffers in subdued, humble silence without intervening initially.
Falls to his knees, sobbing violently and expressing a heartfelt plea to change his ways and honor Christmas in his heart all year round.
Desperately clutches the Phantom's robe and pleads for hope and assurance that he can change.
Recognizes that his current course leads to a negative end and asks if he can change, showing insight into cause and effect.
Falls to his knees and sobs violently in reaction to his future fate, showing emotional overwhelm but also a strong desire to change.
Actively pleads with the Spirit and commits to honoring Christmas and living by the lessons of the Spirits, indicating resolve and willingness to change behavior.
In his agony, babbles like a lunatic upon awakening, showing temporarily unbalanced mental state.
Joyfully expresses gratitude and delight at the possibility of change and redemption; openly celebrates Christmas and wishes happiness to everyone.
Laughs heartily and shows playful, childlike behavior signaling openness and emotional release after long repression.
Greets the boy warmly, compliments him, and speaks kindly, calling him 'my fine fellow' and 'my buck'.
Encourages the boy to buy the large prize turkey for someone else, showing generosity.
His sincerity is not fully believed by the boy leading to the boy's rude reaction.
Pays generously and secretly sends a large turkey to Bob Cratchit's home, shows excitement and joy in the act.
Interacts warmly and cheerfully with the boy and turkey-bearers, expresses holiday greetings.
Quickly devises a plan to send a large turkey anonymously to Bob Cratchit's home, arranges payment promptly, and ensures delivery logistics (calling for a cab due to the turkey's size).
Writes Bob Cratchit's address on a slip of paper to facilitate the delivery, demonstrating attention to detail despite unsteady hand.
Reacts with delight and amusement throughout the transaction showing emotional engagement rather than hesitation or confusion.
Laughs and dances with joy, nicks himself but laughs harder.
Walks with hands behind him, regards everyone with a delighted smile; returns friendly Christmas greetings.
Takes portly gentleman by both hands, offers sincere apology and generous donation without hesitation.
Invites the gentleman to come and see him, expressing gratitude repeatedly.
Rapidly thumbs through hymn-book when he does not know the page, then accepts help from the boy and thanks him.
Puts too much money in the collection plate, then notices the woman's reaction and adjusts by removing some bills with an impish grin.
Walks through the streets observing people, interacting warmly by patting children and questioning beggars, finding pleasure in these activities.
Paces uncertainly outside a house, hesitates before knocking, shakes nervously, and initially prepares to leave before courageously proceeding to knock and seek entrance.
Tenses up as he puts his hand on the sitting-room door’s doorknob, revealing nervousness and uncertainty before entering.
Returns the maid's reassuring smile and gently enters the room despite nervousness.
Apologizes to his niece for startling her upon entering the room.
Attempts to break the ice with a humorous imitation and flashes a happy grin.
Nervously confronts his nephew Fred and sincerely asks to be let in.
Takes a deep breath and gently opens the door despite being scared to enter, showing self-control and initiative.
Flings the door open, startling his niece, then quickly apologizes and corrects his behavior, demonstrating social awareness and adaptability.
Flawlessly imitates The Plump Sister in an attempt to break the ice and lighten the mood, showing social skill and quick thinking.
Momentarily grows sober after guests stare in confusion, possibly indicating a lapse in confidence or awkwardness.
Nervously threads his way through guests and confronts Fred despite feeling awkward and surprised, showing courage and determination.
Dances with guests for the first time in years, joining in celebration.
Keeps his office door wide open to see Bob Cratchit come in, showing openness.
Leaps from his chair and physically digs Bob in the waistcoat despite friendly context.
Attempts to suppress a grin while approximating his old caustic personality.
Raises Bob Cratchit's salary, offers to help his family, invites him to share a Christmas drink, and encourages comfort at home.
Let people laugh at him when he changed and didn't pay attention to their ridicule, understanding that change is often met with skepticism initially.
Was smart enough to keep Christmas well and embody its spirit, showing an ability to live meaningfully and purposefully.
Removes Marley's jaw wrapper, enabling Marley to smile and express gratitude; shakes hands with Marley’s ghost and appears to rejoice in Marley's freedom.
